keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump announced the end of all US payments and subsidies to Colombia, citing Petro’s failure to stop drug production.

The US has provided approximately $210 million in assistance to Colombia this fiscal year, including $31 million in agricultural support, with Trump claiming these funds were a 'long-term rip-off' of America.
Colombia is the world’s leading producer of cocaine, accounting for nearly two-thirds of global production according to the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime.

Trump accused Petro of being an 'illegal drug leader' and called him 'rude and ignorant', while Petro responded by referencing Gabriel García Márquez's novel 'One Hundred Years of Solitude' to critique US policies and values.

The US conducted a series of military strikes in the Caribbean targeting vessels suspected of drug trafficking, with the most recent strike involving a boat linked to a Colombian terrorist group, resulting in the deaths of all three on board.
A previous strike reportedly spared two lives, and Trump announced their return to Colombia and Ecuador, signaling a shift in US approach to civilian casualties.
The US had previously revoked Petro’s visa after he criticized US military actions during a UN visit, escalating diplomatic friction.
The conflict centers on issues of migration, drug trafficking, and national sovereignty, with both leaders accusing each other of failing to address shared challenges.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump announced the end of all US financial payments and subsidies to Colombia, criticizing President Gustavo Petro for failing to curb drug production, which he claims has been enabled by decades of US funding. The US has provided around $210 million in aid this fiscal year, with Colombia being the world’s top cocaine producer. The dispute escalates from prior tensions, including a US military strike on a suspected drug boat in the Caribbean that killed three men, and a controversial visa revocation of Petro after he criticized US actions. Trump personally attacks Petro, calling him an 'illegal drug leader', while Petro responds with a cultural rebuttal referencing Gabriel García Márquez’s 'One Hundred Years of Solitude', asserting that his leadership is rooted in socialism, solidarity, and human life rather than profit or violence. The incident reflects a deepening diplomatic rift between the US and Colombia over migration, drug trafficking, and foreign policy.
title: Trump Escalates Back-and-Forth with Colombia’s President, Announcing End of US Payments to Country
